Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: An introduction to anthropology and the methods by which to study it
Basic concepts and methods in anthropology.
I learned the basis of anthropology and how we view the world, communities, societies, countries, and groups of people from an anthropological lens by learning about ethnographic research methods.
I learned some basic information about anthropology and ethnographic methods
This class was a perfect introduction to anthropology and ethnographic research. I learned a lot about theorists, methods, and ethics that go into anthropologic research.
I learned quite a bit of stuff actually, from Malinowski and ethnographic research to various readings on other cultures. Pretty fun class over all.

I learned a lot about international cultures as well as the everyday culture we are immersed in.  The strange became more familiar and the familiar become strange. This is a course I think everyone at Yale should take to expand their way of thinking and ultimately even interacting with one another.

The main takeaway from this class--that different cultures do things differently, and that we view things through the context of our own culture--is an important thing to know, but it is something that could be conveyed in about twenty minutes rather than over the course of a semester.

I learned a lot about the processes and history behind cultural anthropological research. We learned how to read texts related to anthropological research, how to analyze their findings, and how to apply them to current social issues.

I learned basic concepts and lenses in which people do anthropology, and the second half of the semester really gave us the space to apply those concepts.  You also learn about basic anthropology and the history, how it came to be what it is today.  It is really interesting, and I really want to continue anthropology because of it.  There are also assignments that give you the opportunity to conduct your own mini ethnographies.

This was my first ever anthropology class and it really opened up my mind to thinking about things from a different perspective and the impact that this can have on one's perception of things, such as another culture.
Learned about the fundamental aspects of anthropology and ethnography.
Anthropology
A basic understanding of the field of anthropology: the evolution of the field over time, basic concepts, and techniques for anthropological study.
I gained a basic knowledge of the field of cultural anthropology and the individuals who shaped it.

I learned more about the inner methods of Cultural anthropology. There was good detailing of the proper mindsets to have when immersing into one's culture for study. I  learned about some prominent anthropologists and their impacts and setbacks, which also helped me shape what type of anthropologist I   would want to be.
The ability to think about, observe, evaluate, write about, and relate to a variety of worldviews and cultures, including our own.
I learned that everything is relative and culture is relative and everything is a social construct and blah blah blah.

This course gave an extremely well presented and structure to the field of cultural anthropology.  I learned how to conduct an ethnography, and what an ethnography even is.  We understood the field of anthropology to the point where we could think critically of its limits and benefits as a field, bringing it into conversation with contemporary thoughts.
I learned the basics of cultural anthropology and ethnographic research.
I learned how to consider culture in from a more holistic perspective - I was also introduced to unique, remarkable cultures and traditions from around the world.

This course gives you a tour of historical approaches to anthropology, as well as teaching you about ethnography and frameworks through which to understand other cultures. Excellent for learning key terms and concepts!

Lots of really useful widely applicable vocab. Or rather, the "material" acquisition I got was vocabI feel like the words we learned are attached to interesting and important ways of thinking and evaluating both real life stuff and texts!
A better worldview!
History and theory about the field of anthropology; solid/ethical ethnographical practices; the reach of the field of anthropology.
I learned about and how to practice anthropology.

I learned about a variety of topics related to cultural anthropology: symbols, rituals, structural violence, power, gender, globalization etc. I also learned how to effectively conduct an anthropological study / be a good anthropologist. The first half of the course was spent understanding the foundational concepts and principles of anthropology while during the second half of the course, we were able to analyze how anthropologists put these principles into practice. For example, we read The Land of Open Graves by Jason de Leon, which is both a book and an ethnography about the migrant crossings along the US-Mexico border. He touched on topics such as structural violence, power, agency, culture, etc, in his analysis, which were things that we had discussed earlier in class.
This course was a great introduction to anthropology as a discipline & way of thinking about people in the world.
This class accomplished what anthropology is supposed to do, turn the familiar strange and teh strange familiar.
I have a better sense of the elements of culture, how cultures develop, and how they interact with one another.

In Anthropology 110,  I gained a thorough understanding of anthropological methods.  Within this, I learned a brief history of participant observation, as well as world views, symbols, rituals, and several other components of culture.  I also learned how to write an ethnography and to successfully acquire participant consent.
Intro anthropology and anthropological methods. Leminar style (mix between lecture and seminar)

Strengths: Prof Lombard!!! Material is really interesting, lectures are worthwhile, organization of assignments was great
Weaknesses: n/a
Well-organized.

no weaknesses. 

the setup of the course was impeccable. assignments were fun, engaging, and actually taught me something. exams were fair. lecture was INCREDIBLE, because Lombard is incredible.

I like Louisa's laidback style of teaching and the sections were enjoyable. I also liked being exposed to different worldviews. This class was just a bit too easy at times in terms of what we talked about in class - concepts that could have been much richer and deeper. However, it might fit since it was an introductory class.

Weaknesses: The lecture slides are difficult to follow if not present in class because the professor tells story as she shows pictures on her lecture slides. 

Strengths: Being able to discuss the subject material in smaller groups in section, weekly.

Strengths: course organized very well and the content was great. Professor was one of the most engaging professors I've had in all of my Yale career and all of her classes were thoroughly enjoyable.
Weakness: I think lecture slides could have been a bit more wordy/informative. Having more key terms/concepts/people highlighted in the presentations would have helped us better prepare for the exams.

Learning about the anthropological method and what the discipline is has been interesting. However, the entire second half of the semester felt like each class was just filling time - more could be done to improve the topics and rigor of assignments, rather than just assigning books that felt as though they were picked at random and promoted a particular simplistic political agenda (ie, anyone who works on Wall St. is evil) rather than anything close to a serious scientific discipline.

Strengths: Interesting material, lots of interesting case studies, opportunities to talk with peers, engaging lectures
Weaknesses: Class usually went overtime, which could be improved with better time management. The classroom was also too small to accommodate all of the students, so some students ended up having to sit on the floor for lecture. Perhaps getting a larger classroom or capping the class would allow students to comfortably attend lecture.

This course was very abstract in terms of what you needed to know for tests and projects. I was generally confused on what we were supposed to be learning because it seemed to be a very go with the flow course.

Weaknesses:  Some of the concepts and lectures were too abstract and they were overall very disconnected.  I wish there was a clear relevance of the concepts and themes from each lecture to each other.  We also got off schedule so the readings did not match the lectures, and the professor did not accomodate, so things got a bit confusing.  

Strenghts:  This course covers a lot of ground and there is something that will interest everyone.
Great engagements in lectures and sections.

Strengths: Louisa was an amazing professor. Her lectures were extremely engaging and interesting and made me really enjoy going to class every Monday and Wednesday. 

Weakness: sometimes hard to take good notes as she would just talk and not really put important things on slides
Very interesting class, though I wish the class size had been capped.
Its too basic
Engaging material. Balanced workload.

I really really enjoyed lectures, Professor Lombard was engaging and informative! The tests, however, contained sometimes very specific questions that did not focus on overall understanding so much as niche knowledge.
I really enjoyed Professor Lombards lectures, especially anecdotes about her own fieldwork. I do wish she had gone more into depth on certain subjects, and section felt somewhat pointless.

The course is very indicative of an intro course. It is very beneficial for people who really don't know anything about anthropology and want to see if it's right for them. The weakness is that sometimes it may mistake intro class for high school class. I don't think discussion is as intense as it could be; even the issues that were open-ended didn't really seem to spark that strong of a conflict in the class or within myself. I   didn't have to utilize my mental agility as much as I  felt that I   should have.
Strengths: very engaging and fun assignments, and a fantastic professor.
Its anthropology

This was overall an extremely well structured course.  The conversations in lecture were interesting and engaging, as were all the topics and readings.  On top of that, the readings are not too much to handle, and are oftentimes on interesting ideas.  Lectures are fluid and concepts are explained well by Professor Lombard.  It's a very accessible intro course to anthropology.  If anything could be improved, it would be to engage more with the lengthier texts we read in the second half of the course that were fascinating but felt left out of lectures.
Good course
The class was great! Maybe more in depth into learning about cultural anthropology techniques in class instead of just anecdotes.
The lectures were very engaging and the sections were well-run and helpful.

Professor Lombard is an awesome, engaging lecturer. The lectures are relaxed but interesting. In the first half of the course, the readings were difficult and long but manageable. Later in the course, the books were a bit much. You can still do well and learn a lot sans the assigned reading, but this isnt a great class to take if youre taking a lot of other reading courses.

It was a great course in terms of its content, but necessitated some more incentive in its structure. The readings were interesting, but dense and long enough to make them a daunting task. This, coupled with the absolute separation of the grade from any reading completion/comprehension assessments, made it difficult to find motivation to get through the assigned readings.

The lectures were interesting and interactive, and I think we had good discussions in section.

I perhaps would not expect as much lecture 
participation as the class was a little to big for anyone to feel comfortable. That being said, it was still nice that there was lecture participation, and the students that did speak had thoughtful insights.

I think the course was a very enjoyable course overall. I decided to Credit/D/Fail the course, but I still went to all of the lectures because they were really interesting! Each one was like a TED talk. Professor Lombard would encourage class discussion and would often incorporate video clips or stories about her own travels to supplement the lecture material. I really liked the majority of the readings because they were often an analysis/ethnography about a unique society/group of people somewhere else in the world. I especially liked the books we read (i.e. The Land of Open Graves by Jason de Leon) because they showed me how anthropologists can combine their several years of research into one work that delves into a variety of topics. I didn't find the homework assignments that interesting or useful - we had to be anthropologists analyzing life at Yale. I understand why the homework relates to the course, but I found the lectures and discussion sections to be a lot more engaging and informative.
I think that this course would be better in a seminar format.
The class is very interesting. There is a lot of reading but everything is engaging. One is always learning and the class is dynamic and fun.

strengths: definitely the readings, structure (syllabus) of the course, and group discussions during lectures. also Prof. Lombard is incredibly approachable and engaging--she wants to do everything she can to help us learn and make resources available for us
The readings were exceptional.  I loved Professor Lombard's teaching style.  However, I wish we would have engaged with the readings a little bit more in class.

Strengths: easy, light workload/reading load, no need to show up to lecture, ethnographic assignments are pretty basic, great 5th class whether or not you're interested in anthropology
Weaknesses: i wish the class was a little more intellectually stimulating - at times it felt like a high school class, feedback on ethnographic assignments could have been better/more helpful.

TAKE THIS CLASS!! This is one of my favorite classes I've taken thus far at Yale. Prof Lombard is absolutely wonderful and is a fantastic lecturer, and the class is so interesting. Also, the assignments for the class are actually really interesting, spark interest, and aren't too long that you don't feel like you're wasting time. I don't have enough good things to say about this class.
Yes. Interesting content.

ABSOLUTELY. I dont care what major you are - take this class. Do not credit D it. Take it for a grade. This class was the greatest class I have ever taken at yale - so much so, i declared a double major in anthropology as a second semester junior because I loved this class so much.

I may recommend if you are looking for a light load and an easy and enjoyable class to round out your semester. If you are looking for something that will really challenge you though, this course is not it.

This course is a really great introductory level course, especially if you are interested in majoring in anthropology. But even if you're not thinking of majoring in anthropology, this is a really interesting class to take!

It is definitely a medium workload and you will actually learn a fair amount of anthropology which is very interesting. Id say that the most amazing thing was how Professor Lombard always showed up to lecture with excitement, enthusiasm, and energy even though sometimes you could see that she probably had had a rough morning due to pregnancy. Really goes to show how much love she has for the subject, which really inserts itself into the students.

Yes. I learned a lot about international cultures as well as the everyday culture we are immersed in.  The strange became more familiar and the familiar become strange. This is a course I think everyone at Yale should take to expand their way of thinking and ultimately even interacting with one another.

This course is the biggest gut I've ever taken at Yale - if that's what you're looking for, go for it. 

That being said, I was hoping to get something different out of this class, which is why I feel disappointed with it. I know it is an introductory course, and I have taken introductory courses in the past, but I was genuinely curious about anthropology as a science and was hoping to take a class that treats it seriously and gives students a sense of what the field is really like. I don't like overly critical negative evals, and I realize that the material may be limited by the introductory nature of the class, but this course honestly was entirely devoid of any level of intellectual rigor or critical thinking. It felt to me like each class was "this is how another culture does this thing", which is interesting to learn, but something one could just as easily read on a tourism website or a middle school class. The "ethnographic assignments" that make up the sole homework of the course outside of readings similarly seemed incredibly superficial to me and did not actually produce any real knowledge, discovery, or change in my viewpoint. 

As a minor point, I also was motivated to take this class by the promise in the syllabus to have guest lecturers who would provide insight into potential career paths for anthropology majors outside of academia. Over the entire semester, we only had one guest lecturer, and he was a student who received a fellowship to do academic anthropological research.

If you're genuinely curious or interested in anthropology, I would highly recommend trying a more specialized seminar or some other alternative to this class.
I recommend it if you're interested in learning about anthropological research or are looking for a decent social science credit class.

I would recommend this course to another student if they were interested in this field. I originally thought I was, but it was a bit more abstract than I expected and as a result, it was difficult to discern what was actually important.

I would recommend if you are interested in anthropology and learning to think in a different way.  It is interesting enough, and also not difficult enough.  This is not a challenging course, but I think it is worthwhile.

Yes, take it! It is my first anthropology class but I love it so much. Professor Lombard is an excellent lecturer and she will always keep you engaging in class. I actually look forward to coming to the lecture every day.
Yes, extremely interesting material and Louisa was amazing!
I absolutely would. It was a fascinating course that shed a lot of light on humans and humans within culture.
No
Not exactly a gut, but on-off mildly interesting.
Yes!!!!! You will learn really cool stuff.
Yes, if you need a social science credit. If youre really interested in anthropology, I feel like there are probably more detailed courses you should take. I also think it depends a lot on your TA.

Yes; I  will say that the class is a good, holistic gauge on anthropology and gives advice on how to move forward on an anthropological path. But if you have any experience with what's being discussed-- if you're marginalized, if you've engaged with the social sciences before, then It can be easy to revert to using your own prior knowledge in the class too much. Pushback was hardly a thing I   discovered in this class and it can be disheartening when trying to gain never-before-seen perspectives.
Definitely, this course should be a distributional requirement!
No, unless you legitimately believe the postmodern nonsense.

I would most definitely recommend this to anyone who wants an understanding of what anthropology is.  I myself came in knowing nothing of the field and left feeling knowledgable enough to explain to others about the strengths of anthropology and why it is a useful field.  The class is not a hard class, if you do the readings and study decently well for the exams you'll be fine, and the ethnographic assignments are fun to do.  All around a great class!
Yes
Yes! I loved learning about cultural anthropology! It was a very fun and engaging course!
Yes, it was an interesting introductory course to anthropology. I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in considering human culture.
Great for a taste of anthropology. I learned a lot of basics but also thought the material to be very interesting and relevant to my other social science and humanities courses.

Yes, if they're in my position. I'm not sure I can answer for someone looking to major in Anthropology, and I don't know if the course is a requirement. But I wanted a class to add to an already rigorous schedule which would also allow me to pick up myriad cool ideas and exercises for thought. And that's what I got! Plus, some very cool readings in themselves.
Yes!
The assignments were time-consuming, but a lot of fun. Would probably be a pretty great workload if you're not a humanities-minded person.
Yes, but only if they were excited enough about the material to put in the effort and get the most out of the class.
Yes, the projects were interesting and it is a good introduction to anthropology.

Yes!! I would definitely recommend it, especially if you Credit/D/Fail the class because you can enjoy all of the interesting lectures and readings without worrying too much about your grade. I didn't know anything about anthropology before taking this class, but I was intrigued by the subject. I learned so many topics (ex: symbols, rituals, structural violence, power, gender, globalization, etc.) that have changed the way I view the world. The number one thing we learned is to never be "normative" - we should never think that something is "normal" and compare everything else to this one "normal" method. Anthropology is a unique, interdisciplinary subject that combines biology, economics, psychology, linguistics, etc. I definitely feel that I have learned about the variety among human behavior and societies around the globe.
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course, whether or not your are thinking of majoring in anthropology.
Yes, the class was very fun and interesting. The workload was manageable and engaging.
Yes.

this course is perfect in many ways and I am so glad that I got to take it. Prof. Lombard is the most engaging, candid, and supportive professor I have ever met here and the selection of readings is eye-opening for me

Absolutely.  It was an excellent fifth course, as the requirements were manageable.  It was also great to apply the things I learned in Anthro to my other courses.  Professor Lombard was a wonderful, enthusiastic teacher. I greatly enjoyed this class.
yes! great 5th credit regardless of whether you are interested in anthropology.
